title: Cat. 52  Te po (The Night), 1893/94
publication_title: Gauguin Paintings, Sculpture, and Graphic Works at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Te po (The Night), from the Noa Noa Suite  
1893/94  
Third state of four  
Wood-block print, printed twice in brown and black inks, with selective wiping, and hand-applied red, two tones of orange, yellow, two tones of blue, silver-gray, and black watercolor, on cream laid Japanese paper laid down on cream wove Japanese paper (a laminate made by the artist); 204 × 355 mm (image); 207 × 358 mm (sheets)  
Inscribed in the artist’s hand verso, lower right, in pen and brownish-black ink: 10 Mars / PG [0 changed to 5 in the same ink; upside down]  
The Art Institute of Chicago, Clarence Buckingham Collection, 1948.253  
Guérin 15, Kornfeld 21 III/IV

Printed by Pola Gauguin (Danish, born France, 1883–1961), published by Christian Cato, Copenhagen  
Te po (The Night), from the Noa Noa Suite  
1893/94, printed and published 1921  
Fourth state of four  
Wood-block print in black ink on grayish-ivory China paper; 204 × 358 mm (image); 266 × 425 mm (sheet)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, the Joseph Brooks Fair Collection, 1924.1199  
Guérin 8, Kornfeld 21 IV/IV D,b, Druick/Zegers 16

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Upon his return to France in late August 1893, Gauguin began to prepare an exhibition of painted and sculpted works he had created during his two years in Tahiti. In November forty-one paintings and assorted wood sculptures on Tahitian themes, along with three Brittany-related paintings, were shown in Paris at Durand-Ruel. Only three paintings sold.

When the exhibition closed, the unsold works returned to Gauguin. As photographs of his Paris studio at 6, rue Vercingétorix (see fig. 52.1, fig. 52.2, and fig. 52.3), and eyewitness accounts confirm, Gauguin had painted the walls a bright chrome yellow. The studio also housed paintings and woodcarvings from Gauguin’s Tahitian sojourn that were not exhibited at Durand-Ruel. Thus, by simply looking around his studio, he could select motifs from the array of art displayed on the yellow walls, as well as stacked on the floor, creating a brilliantly colored environment that documented, as well as romanticized, his encounter with the South Seas. Serving as visual aids, the works allowed him to muse upon his adventures as he spun them for fellow artists and literati, made new and experimental work, and wrote and rewrote his travel account and created the accompanying prints using boxwood matrices.

The Noa Noa Suite was printed in two campaigns during Gauguin’s lifetime—one in 1893–94 by the artist himself and the other in 1894 in collaboration with his friend Louis Roy—and received one printing after his death. In 1921 Gauguin’s youngest son, Pola, supervised the publication of a portfolio of black-and-white impressions pulled from eight of the ten surviving boxwood matrices (see fig. 52.4 [Kornfeld 21]) for the suite. Unlike the experimental, expressive, and often hard-to-read impressions made by Gauguin (see cat. 52.1) and the limited but often brighter palette of those printed by Roy, Pola Gauguin’s meticulously inked and pulled prints record in a straightforward manner every detail and represent the prints’ final state. The analysis that follows of what the print depicts relies on a 1921 impression (cat. 52.2), which conveys all of the information that Gauguin inscribed and carved into the woodblock. Gauguin’s intentions for sequencing the plates in his proposed publication were never clear, which has prompted many theories. For the order of plates presented here, see “Veiled in a Cloud of Fragrance.”

While Noa noa, the title page to the suite, is traditionally called plate 1, Te po (The Night) can be considered the first image of the narrative sequence of the prints because of the inclusion here of Gauguin’s monogram, PGo, within the sphere of glowing light at the print’s upper left. This cartouche functions much like the initial letters in early European manuscripts and incunabula signaled the opening of sections and chapters. In Te po, we move from the depiction on the title page of daylight and the activity of food gathering in a fecund natural setting—daily existence as Gauguin documented it in his sketchbooks—to the mysteries and fears of nighttime, sleep, and dreams, a dimension that reflects the interior life and belief systems of Tahitians.

Te po is full of ambiguities. The sky is dominated on the left by a spherical shape, which illuminates a line dividing the sky from a mountainous horizon; at the bottom is a stream in which a fish swims. Compounding the mystery of whether the setting is indoors or out-of-doors is the presence at the bottom right of a burning oil lamp, which could be used inside and out. The central figure, entirely covered except for the head, left shoulder, and extended upper right arm, seems to slumber. However, close examination of the face reveals that the eyes may be half-open, indicating the sleeper’s awareness of presences hovering nearby.

While the petaled orb in the upper left, which Gauguin fashioned as a cartouche, would seem to reference the moon, its form can be linked directly to an image conjured by Charles Morice in verses written for Noa Noa. The poem speaks of the sun as the “fleur des isles” (flower of the [Tahitian] islands) as well as the “soleil de rêve” (sun of dream[s]). Morice asked whether the sun actually shines on real land and people, or whether they are the product of his dream (“mon rêve”). His description of the sun as old and vanquished (“soleil, veilli, vaincu”) is perhaps echoed in the listlessness of the petals surrounding the cartouche in Te po. This blurring of forms further imbues the image with a sense of mystery—it seems to ask, “What is reality, what is dream?”

To suggest the nocturnal universe where Tahitians believed creatures and forces invisible by day revealed themselves, Gauguin fed his imagination with native and non-native references. Because Christian missionaries had destroyed many indigenous objects related to and reflecting religious beliefs of the region, the artist often drew upon Asian and Euro-Christian traditions to help him invent what he could not find visual equivalents for in Tahiti. In the case of the sleeping figure in Te po, he looked to a fresco in the papal basilica of San Francesco in Assisi then thought to be by Giotto di Bondone and now attributed to an anonymous follower of the early Italian Renaissance master. A photograph of this composition was one of a group of miscellaneous materials—photographs, reproductions, prints, and drawings either from or reflecting various cultures, past and present—that the artist often referred to while in Polynesia and that he called his “small circle of comrades.” The depth of Gauguin’s engagement with this photograph is indicated by the fact that he would eventually paste it onto page 236 of his 1896–97 manuscript Diverses choses (Various Things) (fig. 52.5).

Among the frescoes (fig. 52.6 left) is a scene illustrating two apocryphal stories: the arrival of Saint Mary Magdalen at Marseilles and the miraculous recovery of the royal mother and her son abandoned on a desert island (fig. 52.6 center). The recumbent figure in Te po is based on the depiction in the second scene of the shrouded royal mother lying on a tiny rocky outcropping at the composition’s left (fig. 52.6 right). Like the woman in the fresco, the central figure in Te po lies on what seems to be hard ground in a mountainous setting and close to water. At the far left, wavy lines indicate foamy waves breaking over the rock on which the figure rests.

The identity of the wood-block print’s main protagonist as female is confirmed by the image that directly inspired it. It is further underscored by the figure’s presence in a composition that recalls Gauguin’s 1892 Manao tupapau (Spirit of the Dead Watching) (fig. 52.7 [W 457]). In this painting, the artist showed his young mistress, Tehura, as he claimed to have found her one night, terrified by a spirit of death (tupapau) she believed to be lurking nearby, which he depicted as an old woman seen in profile behind the girl.

As indicated above, two sources of light in the print illuminate the dark—at the lower center, a round glass oil lamp, its wick aflame, and at the upper left, the sphere whose rays resemble petals. The shroud that covers the recumbent figure seems to glow from within, while light picks out the edges of other forms in the shadows. Adding a sense of foreboding is the silhouette of a horned devil’s head that the shadow cast by the lamp assumes.

At the lower left, hovering over the plate’s title, Te po, is a fishlike form representing a tii, a spirit that, while belonging to a mystical realm, was considered inferior to the gods in the hierarchy of Polynesian deities. The creature resembles the bottom-dwelling monkfish. A rather large animal, it possesses a huge flat head, gaping mouth, and long tail (see fig. 52.8). Gauguin included a fish with a similar head, but upended and with jellyfish-like tendrils, at the left of a composition in his 1892/93 manuscript Ancien culte mahorie (Ancient Maori Religion) (fig. 52.9). He would repeat this scene, in a more summary way, in his manuscript Noa Noa, Voyage de Tahiti (fig. 52.10).

Behind the reclining female are three figures that may be there to watch over her. That at the far left represents Gauguin, recognizable by the shape of his head, his mustache, and the way he leans his head on one hand (apparently a typical pose for him, since he assumed it in a photograph and in a self-portrait; see fig. 52.11 and fig. 52.12 [W 415]). His presence in Te po suggests his role as a raconteur, tasked with relating Tahiti as fact and Tahiti as dream. This is underscored by the artist’s decision to incorporate his monogram within the shining, petaled orb, as if to say that his role was to shed light on Tahitian customs and beliefs through his written account Noa Noa and the wood-block prints that were to accompany it. Gauguin used his mistress the way a ventriloquist employs a puppet, channeling Polynesian cosmology and related subjects through the lens of her image and stories, as well as that of Jacques-Antoine Moerenhout’s 1837 study of South Seas religious beliefs, which he read. The resulting representations are an amalgam of images and ideas that, in the end, are Gauguin’s own.

Next to Gauguin is a ghostly presence, or tupapau, a spirit of the dead, whose face is partly obscured by one hand and shadow and whose body is barely articulated. Its form recalls that of a Peruvian mummy in the Musée d’Ethnographie du Trocadéro, Paris, that Gauguin sketched several times (see fig. 52.13, fig. 52.14, and fig. 52.15).

Most clearly delineated is the figure at the right, a malevolent spirit (varau’ino) whose face and torso confront the viewer directly. Gauguin was fond of this motif; one finds it in a number of his paintings, in particular Parau na te varua ino (Words of the Devil) and a graphite study for it (fig. 52.16 [W 458, Field 1977 29]), and fig. 52.17 [Pickvance 64]). The devil motif figures in two other paintings from the same year, Barbaric Tales (fig. 52.18 [W 459]) and Parau hanohano (Terrifying Words) (fig. 52.19 [W 460] ). Gauguin executed variations of the latter painting in a wood relief of 1891/93 (fig. 52.20 [Gray 134]), three cover or title-page designs from 1893 (fig. 52.21, fig. 52.22, and fig. 52.23), a zincograph of 1893/94 (fig. 52.24 [Kornfeld 24]), and a pen-and-ink sketch of 1894 (fig. 52.25; woodcut monograph stamp, bottom right [Kornfeld 28]). Later he would paste a cutout of the devil from the zincograph onto the inside front cover of his 1903 manuscript Avant et après (Before and After) (fig. 52.26).

The recumbent-female motif features in studies from life found on page 68 of the 1891–93 Carnet de Tahiti (Tahitian Sketchbook) (fig. 52.27). Here a masculine-looking figure stands above her, much as Gauguin placed himself above the sleeping protagonist of Te po. A roughly contemporary watercolor (fig. 52.28) features a row of three reclining figures above another sleeping woman. The image of a female in repose first appeared in the right foreground of Gauguin’s 1892 canvas Te fare hymenee (House of Song) (fig. 52.29 [W 477, Field 1977 22]), in which two figures sleep in the foreground while a large social gathering takes place in the background. The artist incorporated the motif as well into two other paintings from that year: in Moe moea (The Dream) (fig. 52.30), a supine woman wearing a pareu occupies the entire width of the composition; an oil lamp at the upper left illuminates her and a second figure sleeps in the middle ground; and in Reclining Figure in Candlelight, one finds a composition very close to that of Te po, except in reverse.

On page 60 of his bound 1893–1901 manuscript Noa Noa, Voyage de Tahiti, Gauguin pasted a fragment of Te po (fig. 52.31) and on page 63 mounted a watercolor version of Te fare hymenee (fig. 52.32). This watercolor served as the model for a late wood-block print, Interior of a Tahitian Hut (fig. 52.33 [cat. 92.2]). Included in various contexts, most of these reclining women were not intended to embody the sense of mystery and disquiet that Gauguin achieved in Te po. Significantly, Gauguin returned to the subject in plate 10 of Noa Noa, Manao tupapau (She Thinks of the Ghost or The Ghost Thinks of Her) (cat. 60), in which a reclining nude lies with her back to the viewer, signaling perhaps how isolating the experience of fearing spirits of the dead can be.  
Peter Zegers

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry2" id="curatorial_entry2">The title of this plate, Te po, inscribed in large capital letters at the bottom left, is a noun (with article) meaning “the night,” which particularly fits the obscurity of Gauguin’s images. In addition, pō designates an ontological realm beyond tangible realities. In Le mariage de Loti by Pierre Loti (pseudonym for Julien Viaud), published in 1879, the narrator is struck by the “vast number of mystical words derived from the old Maori religion” found in a dictionary of the Tahitian language and mentions the translation of pō as “night, the ancient past, an unknown dark world, hell.” Pō was opposed to ao, “day,” within a dualistic worldview summarized as follows by the anthropologist E. S. Craighill Handy in 1927:

. . . the Polynesian dualism placed on the positive side nature superior, the sacred and divine, the psychic, superior power (mana), the male principle, light, life, occult knowledge, the east and day (ao), and the strong, right side of man; while on the negative side were included nature inferior, the common and unsacred, the physical, the passive, receptive female principle, darkness, destructive influences and death, ignorance, the west and night (po), and the left or weak side.

This title makes clear that this work (and by implication the Noa Noa Suite as a whole) is not a genre scene. It seeks to give visual form not only to “the delightful realities of the present,” but also to “the myths of the past”—and maybe to show that these “myths” are alive in the present. The nocturnal scene features a reclining female figure, covered with what seems to be a blanket, rather than clothing, and appearing to sleep. Peter Zegers identifies a stream with a fish at the bottom and observes that the setting is ambiguous (see Descriptive Analysis and Related Works): the ascending line suggests the ridge of a mountain, therefore an outdoor scene, while the burning oil lamp can also be associated with an interior.

The luminous sphere in the upper-left corner is equally ambiguous. Given the nightly atmosphere, it should represent the moon, but the petal-like shapes surrounding it evoke depictions of the sun as well as the flower most closely associated with it, the sunflower. The fact that Gauguin chose to place his monogram within this sphere implies a special link, which can be conceptualized in several ways. Zegers interprets it as expressing the artist’s self-appointed mission of shedding “light on Tahitian customs and beliefs” (see Descriptive Analysis and Related Works). The sunflower, presenting its blossom to the sun, was an emblem of painting as an art of imitation, used as such for example in a famous self-portrait by Anthony van Dyck (fig. 52.34). Gauguin had an additional reason for identifying with this plant: his descent on his mother’s side from a Peruvian family and claim that this genealogy might include indigenous blood, together with the fact that the sunflower had reached Europe from the Americas via Peru and played a part in the pre-conquest cult of the sun. In 1888, planning a stay in Martinique, he had explained the attraction he felt for the Tropics to a friend: “The Inca, according to the legend, came directly from the sun and I shall return there.” The flower also evoked for him the memory of Vincent van Gogh, whom he had depicted as “the painter of sunflowers” (fig. 52.35 [W 296, W 2002, 326]). The connection was based on Van Gogh’s own identification with the flower, which was adopted by the Dutch artist’s admirers and led to his being represented as one (with martyr’s aureole) on the catalogue cover of his 1892 posthumous exhibition in Amsterdam (fig. 52.36).

Additionally, the visual oxymoron of a dark sun calls to mind the artistic and literary reception of Albrecht Dürer’s print Melancholia I (fig. 52.37), whose comet falling within a rainbow (also in the upper-left corner) was consistently described and appropriated as a “black sun” in the nineteenth century. Most famously, the French writer Gérard de Nerval placed himself under the sign of “the black sun of Melancholy” in his poem “El desdichado” (“The Miserable One”) and used this motif for a comparison between Europe and the Tropics in his Voyage to the Orient (1851); although the world he discovered in Cairo struck him as “the perfect antithesis” of the one he had fled, he wrote that he did not always feel happier there, because “the black sun of melancholy . . . sometimes also rises above the luminous plains of the Nile.”

Within the body of work realized by Gauguin during his first stay in Tahiti, the main antecedent of Te po is the painting Te fare hymenee (House of Songs) (fig. 52.38 [W 477]), which depicts a traditional nightly social gathering in a communal long house, with two women sleeping in the foreground. The print focuses on one of these figures and introduces an ambiguity of scale, since the curved shapes situated behind her and upon which her head and right arm seem to rest resemble hills or mountains more than pillows, sleepers, or dogs. This can be partly accounted for by the artistic source that Gauguin employed for this figure, a fourteenth-century fresco in Assisi then believed to be by Giotto, of which he possessed a photograph (fig. 52.39). Because of the symbolic character of the scene and of the artist’s use of hierarchical proportions, its female protagonist resembles a giant lying on a diminutive island. The suggested analogy between the woman, self-contained in her red garment, and the island surrounded by the sea may have appealed to Gauguin when he detached the sleeping Tahitian from those who are awake.

In Te po, the three figures sitting behind the reclining one are not other Tahitians gathered for a hīmene—a polyphonic chant named after religious hymns—but otherworldly beings. The burning lamp may refer to ghosts (tūpāpa’u) since, in his 1893 Cahier pour Aline (Notebook for Aline), Gauguin wrote that Tahitians had “a constant fear of them. At night a lamp is always burning.” But its apotropaic efficacy appears doubtful, as it shares sinister features with the creatures it is meant to keep at bay. Peter Zegers observes rightly that the shadow it casts assumes the silhouette of a horned devil’s head (see Descriptive Analysis and Related Works) and the lamp itself, while probably inspired by the upper part of a glass oil lamp, resembles the spherical explosives with a fuse sticking out that the anarchist bombings had by then turned into Western symbols of terror. Even the way in which the flame interrupts the outline of the woman’s garment suggests that her protective envelope is not impregnable and may introduce a sexual connotation.

Zegers identifies the three figures in the background as representing (from left to right) Gauguin himself, a tūpāpa’u derived from a Peruvian mummy, and a vārua ‘ino or “evil spirit” (see Descriptive Analysis and Related Works). Gauguin’s presence, according to Zegers, “suggests his role as a raconteur, tasked with relating Tahiti as fact and Tahiti as dream.” This supports the argument for considering Te po as the second plate of the Noa Noa Suite, immediately following the title page (see “Veiled in a Cloud of Fragrance”). It may not be the only self-representation of the artist in the series, however, and the position with the head resting on one hand, while typical of Gauguin, is also a main attribute of the representations of melancholy, included in countless allegories and self-portraits from Dürer’s Melancholia I to the late nineteenth century and beyond. Gauguin’s uncanny characters also recall iconographically more easily identifiable triads such as the antique Moirai and Parcae, or the incestuous family of the Devil, Sin, and Death in Milton’s Paradise Lost.

Stephen Eisenman opposed the “physicality and mortality” of the reclining woman to the “spirituality and eternality” of the “old and ghostly spirits at right.” A comparison with the artist’s 1892 painting Manao tupapau (Spirit of the Dead Watching) (fig. 52.40 [W 457]), which also features a reclining young woman—in this case naked—confronted with a “spirit of the dead,” illuminates the nature of the relationship between these unlikely companions. As Gauguin explained, the title can mean either that the terrified woman thinks of (or believes in) the tūpāpa’u, or that the spirit thinks of her or watches over her (see cat. 60). “Watching over” is an apt description of the passive but vigilant attitude of the spiritual trio in Te po, and the ontological reversibility established by the title Manao tupapau may also apply to the wood-block print: the spirits, even though immaterial, are no less “real” than the living human being. This also can be said of the fish, which hovers at the limit of recognizability and is hardly more substantial than the shadow-devil preceding its progression to the right—especially in Gauguin’s hand-colored impression of the print (cat. 52.1), which greatly accentuates the ghostly character of the whole scene. According to Zegers (see Descriptive Analysis and Related Works), this fish could represent a ti’i, one of the “spirits inferior to gods” listed by J.-A. Moerenhout and which served as an “intermediary and demarcation line between organic and inorganic beings” (see cat. 54, Commentary).

One way of understanding the relationship between the reclining woman and the supernatural beings surrounding her is to think of them as elements of her dream. As early as 1881, Gauguin had demonstrated his interest in dreams and his ambition to include oneiric images in his paintings with The Little One Is Dreaming (fig. 52.41), a depiction of his daughter Aline asleep under pseudo-wallpaper that suggests the movements of her imagination. For French oneirologists such as Alfred Maury, whose research was widely disseminated, the dream represented a psychic regression to earlier stages of development, both of the individual and of the species. These conceptions, on which Sigmund Freud built his notion of the conservation of archaic modes of thought in the subconscious, are compatible with the understanding of pō as “ancient times,” preceding the colonization and Christianization of Polynesia, or even as “the primeval darkness that . . . existed before the earth was created.” The “evil spirits” are, to some extent, the ancient gods supplanted by Jehovah who return under cover of the night. Robert Louis Stevenson concluded from his 1888 voyage over the Pacific:

. . . in the whole field of the South Seas . . . all men believe in ghosts, all men combine with their recent Christianity fear and a lingering faith in the old island deities. So, in Europe, the gods of Olympus slowly dwindled into village bogies; so to-day, the theological Highlander sneaks from under the eye of the Free Church divine to lay an offering by a sacred well.

Gauguin would have agreed with the Scottish author’s comparison of Polynesian beliefs with European “superstitions.” In 1888 he had painted in Brittany Vision of the Sermon (Jacob Struggling with the Angel) ([W 245, W 2002 308] (see “Veiled in a Cloud of Fragrance”). It may seem strange that he included his own image among the “spirits” in Te po, but this is consistent with the incorporation of his monogram into the “black sun” and with the fact that, in the 1901 version of Noa Noa, the narrator telling the anecdote behind Manao tupapau wonders whether his Tahitian mistress, whom he finds in the dark on his return from Papeete, does not take him “for one of the demons and specters . . . with whom the legends of her race fill the sleepless nights.” Like Francisco Goya, who depicted himself assailed by “monsters” engendered by “the sleep of reason” (fig. 52.42), Gauguin saw as part of his task the evocation of the nocturnal side of experience, whatever the latitude.  
Dario Gamboni

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">In the catalogue are two entries listing tikis, carved images of a Polynesian god or ancestor. The three buyers were Michel Manzi, who purchased Ia orana Maria (Hail Mary) (1891; Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York [W 428)]; Edgar Degas, who bought Hina tefatou (Moon and Earth) (1893; Museum of Modern Art, New York [W 499]); and Wilhelm Hansen, who acquired Vahine no te tiare (Flower Woman) (1891; Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek, Copenhagen [W 420]). Galeries Durand-Ruel, Exposition d’oeuvres récentes de Paul Gauguin (Galeries Durand-Ruel, Nov. 1893), nos. 1, 5, and 31, respectively.

Figure 52.3 was first published in Douglas W. Druick and Peter Zegers, Paul Gauguin: Pages from the Pacific, exh. cat. (Auckland City Art Gallery in association with the Art Institute of Chicago, 1995), p. 25. There is a contemporary description of Gauguin’s studio:

Au fond, était un hangar vitré, comportant un rez-de-chausée et deux étages. En haut de l’escalier, à la hauteur de second, un balcon desservait trois ateliers. Le troisième et dernier de ceux-ci, au bout de balcon, était celui de Gauguin. . . . Au bout de l’antichambre se trouvait l’atelier. . . . Cette assez vaste pièce, entièrement peinte en jaune de chrome clair—chrome no. 1—donnait la sensation immédiate de l’étrange et de l’imprévue. Sur les murs, balafrés de toiles barbares. (At the back was a kind of windowed shed with a ground floor and two upper stories. At the top of the stairs at the second level, a balcony led to three studios. The third and last of these, at the balcony’s far end, was Gauguin’s. . . . An entrance space led to the studio. . . . This rather vast room, painted entirely in bright chrome yellow—chrome no. 1—created an immediate impression of strangeness and unpredictability. On the walls, smeared with barbaric canvases.)

Jean de Rotonchamp [Louis Brouillon], Paul Gauguin 1848–1903 (É. Druet, 1906), pp. 123–24. Colta Ives identified the man at the lower-left corner of the photograph as Gauguin, wearing the Stetson hat he purchased after viewing Buffalo Bill Cody’s Wild West Show at the 1889 Exposition Universelle, Paris. Colta Ives and Susan Alyson Stein, The Lure of the Exotic: Gauguin in New York Collections, exh. cat. (Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2002), p. 12, fig. 18. The facial structure and costume of the man in the photograph are closely related to those of Gauguin’s Self-Portrait with Hat (1893/94; Musée d’Orsay, Paris [W 506]).

The order presented here—first proposed in Douglas W. Druick and Peter Zegers, Paul Gauguin: Pages from the Pacific, exh. cat. (Auckland City Art Gallery/Art Institute of Chicago, 1995), pp. 23–24—reflects the unfolding of a narrative based on the themes of the ten wood-block prints. Bronwen Nicholson offered another point of view: “Dans leur ensemble, les gravures sur bois nous montrent le cycle de la vie à la tahitienne, décrivant les aspects de Tahiti qui ont saisi l’imagination de Gauguin: la naissance et la mort, l’amour et la procréation, le bain, la quête de la nourriture, les légendes tahitiennes” (Taken together, the woodcuts show us the Tahitian life cycle, describing the aspects of Tahiti that had captured Gauguin’s imagination: birth and death, love and procreation, bathing, the quest for nourishment, Tahitian legends). Bronwen Nicholson, Noa Noa, transcription, ed. Pierre Petit (J. J. Pauvert, 1988), pp. 113, 123–38.

For yet another approach, which marries the prints to the way the text is ordered, see Alastair Wright and Calvin Brown, Gauguin’s Paradise Remembered: The Noa Noa Prints, exh. cat. (Princeton University Art Museum/Yale University Press, 2010). In the opinion of Starr Figura, the wood-block prints do not follow a narrative; she divided them into three thematic categories: “portrayals of daily life, night-time scenes of figures communing with or haunted by spirits, and images depicting Tahitian gods and myths.” Starr Figura, “Noa Noa and the Tahitian Idyll,” in Figura, Gauguin: Metamorphoses, with essays by Elizabeth Childs, Hal Foster, and Erika Mosier (Museum of Modern Art, New York, 2013), p. 92.

Between 1893 and 1895, Gauguin worked closely with Morice on his planned publication of Noa Noa. Based on discussions with the artist, the stories he related, and his Tahitian paintings, Morice wrote poems for the publication that Gauguin copied onto page 52 into his manuscript. The third stanza of the poem “La Vivo” reads: “O drapeau de soleil que l’océan déploie / Triomphal dans les ciels splendides de midi / Fleur des Îles, es-tu le Réel Paradis? / O vaste fleur de faste! O fleur de jeune joie!” (This sunlit streamer that the ocean unfolds, / Triumphs over the magnificent noon skies. / Flower of the Islands, are you a Real Paradise? / Vast bloom of light! The bloom of youth’s delight!). Noa Noa, Voyage de Tahiti, 1893–1901, p. 52. Musée d’Orsay, Paris, given by Georges-Daniel de Monfreid, 1927, RF 7259. A second poem, “La vivo—le soir,” is closely related to Te po, as the following lines demonstrate: “Le vent de l’éternel été s’endort dans l’air Vespéral / Le soleil, vieilli, vaincu, récule / Devant la jeune lune au bord du crépuscule / Se dressant, radieuse, et leurs feux, un moment / Sur la crête des flots qui dansent, mollement. S’entrebaisent—et sur la tête solitaire / De l’Arorai, temple et sommet de la terre / D’ou le Rideau est bois dérobe à tous les yeux / La gloire, la douleur et le sécret des Dieux”). Gauguin did not include this poem in his manuscript. Rather, it appeared in the version of Noa Noa that Morice prepared without Gauguin’s involvement (much to his dismay) and published in La Plume 289 (May 1, 1901), pp. 64–65. Whether or not Gauguin knew this poem at the time he and Morice worked together on Noa Noa, it clearly reflects ideas and images they had shared.

Gauguin wrote to the artist Odilon Redon before his departure for Tahiti, “Gauguin is finished here; he will be seen no more. You see that I am an egotist. I am taking along photographs, drawings, a small circle of comrades who will speak to me about you every day” (“Gauguin est fini ici, on ne verra plus rien de lui. Vous voyez que je suis égoiste. J’emporte en photographies, dessins, tout un petit monde de camarades que me vous causeront tous les jours”). Lettres de Gauguin, Gide, Huysmans, Jammes, Mallarmé, Verhaeren . . . à Odilon Redon, ed. Roseline Bacou and Arï Redon (J. Corti, 1960), p. 193.

The full story is as follows: the governor of Marseilles and his pregnant wife embark on a pilgrimage at the behest of Mary Magdalen, traveling by sea to Rome. After his wife dies in childbirth, the distraught governor docks his ship alongside an island in order to bury her. The ground is hard, forcing him to place her body on a cloth and put their still-living child at her breast. In Rome the bereaved pilgrim meets Saint Peter and spends two years traveling to sacred sites. Finally, on his journey home, he returns to the island, where he finds his son alive (having been miraculously nursed by his still-dead mother); the governor prays to the Magdalen and witnesses his wife restored to life. The apocryphal story was one of many recorded beginning in the mid-thirteenth century by Jacobus de Voragine and published in his The Golden Legend, Readings on the Saints. See William Granger Ryan’s translation (Princeton University Press, 1993), pp. 374–83.

Gauguin turned to the writing of Jacques-Antoine Moerenhout in matters related to the Tahitian pantheon of gods. Moerenhout observed, “The Tiis would have some similarities with our devils or demons” (“Les Tiis aurient en ceci, quelques rapports avec nos diables ou demons”). Jacques-Antoine Moerenhout, Voyages aux îles du grand océan (A. Bertrand, 1837), vol. 1, p. 461.

Jacques-Antoine Moerenhout, Voyages aux îles du grand océan (A. Bertrand, 1837), vol. 1, p. 461.

Not having sold at the Durand-Ruel exhibition, this 1892 canvas was in Gauguin’s studio while he was engaged in his Noa Noa project. The study belonged to a portfolio containing miscellaneous drawings, now dispersed, which Gauguin entitled “Documents Tahiti 1891 1892 1893.” See Exposition Gauguin. Aquarelles, monotypes, dessins, preface by Marcel Guérin (Galerie Marcel Guiot, 1942), no. 81, pp. 38, 41 (ill.).

Parau hanohano was included in Galeries Durand-Ruel, Exposition d’oeuvres récentes de Paul Gauguin (Galeries Durand-Ruel, 1893), no. 11 (as Faire peur [To Frighten]), but it did not sell.

The texts incorporated into these cover and/or title-page images are difficult to read because the ink has faded. The first (fig. 52.21) is inscribed and dated within the composition Catalogue / [Tah]iti 93; the second (fig. 52.22) is inscribed within the composition Parau Parau no / Gauguin; the third (fig. 52.23) is inscribed, dated, and signed within the composition O Tahiti / An 92–93 / Paul Gauguin.

The artist passed over this work when making selections for his November 1893 exhibition at Durand-Ruel.

Based on study of color reproductions, the attribution to Gauguin of both Moe moea and Reclining Figure in Candlelight seems questionable. For Reclining Figure, see Kunstmuseum Bern, “Nachlass Gurlitt—Salzburger Kunstfund,” no. 15, http://www.kunstmuseumbern.ch, accessed Dec. 12, 2014.

On the one-to-one relationship between the watercolor and the wood-block print, see cat. 92, Descriptive Analysis and Related Works.

“Nuit, ancien temps, moderne inconnu et ténébreux, enfers.” Pierre Loti [Julien Viaud], Le mariage de Loti [Rarahu: Idylle polynésienne] (1879), ed. Bruno Vercier (Flammarion, 1991), pt. 1, chap. 18, p. 18; trans. Clara Bell (Werner Laurie, 1925), p. 30. The dictionary to which the character Loti refers is Tepano Jaussen, Grammaire et dictionnaire de la langue maorie, dialecte tahitien (Toinon, 1861); see http://www.arapo.org.pf/dico.html?, accessed Nov. 28, 2015. The translation of pō in John Davies’s Tahitian and English Dictionary (London Missionary Society Press, 1851) is “night. / the unknown world, or hades; the place of punishment in the other world. / antiquity, unknown, ancient date.”

E. S. Craighill Handy, “Polynesian Religion,” Bishop Museum Bulletin 34 (1927), p. 37.

The expressions are quoted from Octave Mirbeau, “Retour de Tahiti,” L’écho de Paris, Nov. 14, 1893, p. 1.

Gauguin to Émile Schuffenecker, c. Dec. 20, 1888, in Correspondance de Paul Gauguin: Documents; Témoignages, ed. Victor Merlhès, vol. 1, 1873–88 (Fondation Singer-Polignac, 1984), p. 305, [letter 193].

The drooping petals on Roland Holst’s poster, which refer to Van Gogh’s tragic life and death, can be compared to the downward direction of the petal-like shapes in Te po, which Peter Zegers interprets as a sign of listlessness and relates to the “vanquished sun” in a poem written by Charles Morice for Noa Noa (see Descriptive Analysis and Related Works)—to which one might add Gauguin’s own reference to Van Gogh with partly drooping sunflowers in the painting Sunflowers in an Armchair (1901; Hermitage State Museum, St. Petersburg [W 603]). On this point, see Dario Gamboni, Paul Gauguin: The Mysterious Centre of Thought, trans. Chris Miller (Reaktion, 2014), pp. 356–58. However, the downward direction may also be interpreted as a movement toward the earth and the scene below, as in depictions of the ancient Egyptian sun god. For a discussion of the sunflowers and their association with Gauguin’s Peruvian ancestry, see Douglas W. Druick and Peter Kort Zegers, Van Gogh and Gauguin: The Studio of the South, in collaboration with Britt Salvesen, with contributions to the text by Kristen Hoermann Lister, and the assistance of Mary C. Weaver, exh. cat. (Art Institute of Chicago/Van Gogh Museum/Thames & Hudson, 2001), pp. 84–88.

See Ulrich Finke, “Dürers Melancholie in der französischen und englischen Literatur des 19. Jahrhunderts,” Zeitschrift des Deutschen Vereins für Kunstwissenschaft 30 (1976), pp. 67–85.

Gérard de Nerval, Oeuvres complètes, ed. Jean Guillaume and Claude Pichois (Gallimard, 1984–93), vol. 2 (1984), p. 301, and vol. 2, p. 645.

For sketches for this painting and variations on its theme, see Descriptive Analysis and Related Works, fig. 27, fig. 28, fig. 29, fig. 30, and fig. 31. The sleeping woman in an architectural context reappears in Gauguin’s later wood-block print Interior of a Tahitian Hut (cat. 92). On Gauguin’s experience of the complete darkness of night in Tahiti, see Bronwen Nicholson, “La suite de gravures sur bois de Noa Noa,” in Paul Gauguin, Noa Noa, transcription, ed. Pierre Petit, commentary by Bronwen Nicholson (J.-J. Pauvert, 1988), pp. 135–36, with reference to Gauguin’s trip to the valley of Punaru’u (p. 61). See also Nicholas Wadley, ed., Noa Noa: Gauguin’s Tahiti, trans. Jonathan Griffin (Phaidon, 1985), pp. 28–32.

One can only speculate about Gauguin’s knowledge of the story depicted, a miracle performed by Mary Magdalen and related in Jacobus de Voragine’s Golden Legend (see Descriptive Analysis and Related Works, n. 6), and on its relevance for Te po.

As early as July 1892, when Gauguin had been in Tahiti for less than a month, he wrote to his wife that he had attended hīmene and enthused about their musical harmony. Gauguin to Mette Gauguin, July 1891, in Paul Gauguin: Letters to His Wife and Friends, ed. Maurice Malingue, trans. Henry J. Stenning (World, 1949), pp. 162–63, no. 126. For a comparison between this music and Gauguin’s work, see Jehanne Teilhet-Fisk, Paradise Reviewed: An Interpretation of Gauguin’s Polynesian Symbolism (UMI Research Press, 1983), pp. 26–27.

Paul Gauguin, Cahier pour Aline (1893) (Éds. du Sonneur, 2009), p. 32. The tūpāpa’u and the fear it inspired among Tahitians is a leitmotif in Pierre Loti [Julien Viaud], Le mariage de Loti. See also, for example, Robert Louis Stevenson, In the South Seas (1896) (Chatto & Windus, 1924), pt. 1, chap. 4, p. 33: “The fear of ghosts and of the dark is very deeply written in the mind of the Polynesian; not least of the Marquesan.”

See William Hauptman, “The Persistence of Melancholy in 19th-Century Art: The Iconography of a Motif” (Ph.D. diss., Pennsylvania State University, 1975); and Peter-Klaus Schuster, “Das Bild der Bilder. Zur Wirkungsgeschichte von Dürers Melancholiekupferstich,” Idea. Jahrbuch der Hamburger Kunsthalle 1 (1982), pp. 72–134.

Stephen F. Eisenman, “Te Po, or Eternal Night,” in Paul Gauguin: Artist of Myth and Dream, ed. Stephen F. Eisenman, exh. cat. (Skira, 2007), p. 312, cat. 88.

Stephen Eisenman suggested that the three spirits could also be mourners in a deathbed scene, awaiting “the arrival of the soul of the dying girl.” Stephen F. Eisenman, “Te po, or Eternal Night,” in Paul Gauguin: Artist of Myth and Dream, ed. Stephen F. Eisenman, exh. cat. (Skira, 2007), p. 312, cat. 88. This is a possible but not probable interpretation. Zegers notes that the eyes of the reclining figure “may be half-open” (see Descriptive Analysis and Related Works), but the observation is too tentative and ambiguous to conclude much about her situation.

L.-F.-Alfred Maury, Le sommeil et les rêves (1862) (Didier, 1878), pp. 377–85. See Jacqueline Carroy and Nathalie Richard, eds., Alfred Maury, érudit et rêveur: Les sciences de l’homme au milieu du XIXe siècle (Presses Universitaires de Rennes, 2007).

Bengt Danielsson, “Gauguin’s Tahitian Titles,” Burlington Magazine 109, no. 769 (Apr. 1967), p. 233, no. 71.

Robert Louis Stevenson, In the South Seas (1896) (Chatto & Windus, 1924), pt. 2, chap. 6, p. 188.

Paul Gauguin and Charles Morice, Noa Noa (La Plume, 1901), p. 134.

On the ambivalence of Goya’s Caprice 43, which may have been planned as a frontispiece for Los Caprichos, see Werner Hofmann, “Der Traum der Vernunft oder: Täter und Opfer,” in Goya: Das Zeitalter der Revolutionen, 1789–1830, exh. cat. (Prestel, 1980), pp. 52–61. Gauguin published an article, “Sous deux latitudes,” in which he compared Tahiti and Paris, in Essais d’art libre 5 (May 1894), pp. 75–80.

fig. 52.1 Exterior of Paul Gauguin’s studio at the back of the courtyard at 6, rue Vercingétorix, 14th arrondissement (Montparnasse), Paris. Gauguin’s studio was on the second floor at left (here highlighted in yellow).

fig. 52.2 Paul Gauguin’s Paris studio interior with, left to right, front row: Paul Gauguin, the musicians Fritz Schneklud and Larrivel; back row: the painter Paul Sérusier, Annah “the Javanese,” and the sculptor Georges Lacombe. Photograph. Musée Gauguin, Papeari. For the identification of the paintings seen behind the figures, see fig. 52.3.

fig. 52.3 Reconstruction of Gauguin’s studio at 6, rue Vercingétorix, Paris, based on an 1894 photograph (fig. 52.2). On the chrome yellow wall behind the group are the following paintings by Gauguin: top left, Mata mua (In Olden Times) (1892; Carmen Thyssen-Bornemisza Collection, on loan at the Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza [W 467]); top right, Pastorales tahitiennes (Tahitian Pastorals) (1892; State Hermitage Museum, Saint Petersburg [W 470]); bottom left, Arii matamoe (The Royal End) (1892; J. Paul Getty Museum, Los Angeles ([W 453]); bottom right, Te fare maorie (The House of the Maori/The Native Hut) (1891; private collection, Switzerland [W 436]). First published in black and white in Douglas W. Druick and Peter Zegers, Paul Gauguin: Pages from the Pacific, exh. cat. (Auckland City Art Gallery/Art Institute of Chicago, 1995), p. 25.

fig. 52.4 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Te po (The Night), 1893/94. Commercial composite boxwood matrix with traces of zinc white and ink; 20.6 × 35.6 × 2.3 cm (8 1/8 × 14 × 7/8 in.). Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, gift of Philip Hofer, Esq., 57.83.

fig. 52.5 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Photograph published by Fratelli Alinari, no. 15739, of a fresco by a follower of Giotto (Italian, 1266–1337), Mary Magdalene's Voyage to Marseilles, from Scenes from the Life of Mary Magdalene (1320s; Magdalene Chapel, Lower Church, Basilica of Saint Francis of Assisi), pasted onto fol. 122V of the manuscript Diverses choses (Various Things), 1896–98. Musée d’Orsay, Paris, given by Georges-Daniel de Monfrield, 1927, RF 7259, 232–33.

fig. 52.6 Follower of Giotto di Bondone (Italian, 1266–1337). Frescoes from Scenes from the Life of Mary Magdalene, Magdalene Chapel, Lower Church, Basilica of Saint Francis of Assisi, Assisi. 1320s. Left, Arrival of Saint Mary Magdalen at Marseilles and Miraculous Recovery of the Royal Mother and Her Son Abandoned on a Desert Island. Center, Recovery of the Royal Mother and Her Son Abandoned on a Desert Island. Right, Royal Mother and Her Son.

fig. 52.7 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Manao tupapau (Spirit of the Dead Watching), 1892. Oil on burlap mounted on canvas; 73 × 92 cm (28 3/4 × 36 1/4 in.). Albright-Knox Gallery, A. Conger Goodyear Collection, Buffalo, 1965, 1965:1.

fig. 52.8 Monkfish (Lophius piscatorius).

fig. 52.9 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Ti’ii (Inferior Spirits), fol. 11R from the manuscript Ancien culte mahorie (Ancient Maori Religion), 1892/93. Pen and ink, brush and watercolor on paper; 21.5 × 17 cm (8 7/16 × 6 11/16 in.). Musée d’Orsay, Paris, bequest of Étienne Moreau-Nélaton, 1927, RF 10755, 21.

fig. 52.10 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Ti’ii (Inferior Spirits), fol. 30V from the bound manuscript Noa Noa, Voyage de Tahiti, 1893–1901. Pen and ink, brush and watercolor; 31 × 23.3 cm (12 3/16 × 9 3/16 in.). Musée d’Orsay, Paris, given by Georges-Daniel de Monfreid, 1927, RF 7259, 60.

fig. 52.11 Louis-Maurice Boutet de Monvel (French, 1851–1913). Paul Gauguin Wearing a Breton Jacket, 1891. Aristotype photograph; 11.1 × 9.2 cm (4 1/4 × 3 3/8 in.). Musée Départemental Maurice Denis le Prieuré, Saint-Germain-en Laye.

fig. 52.12 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Self-Portrait with Idol, 1893. Oil on canvas; 43.8 × 32.7 cm (17 1/4 × 12 7/8 in.). McNay Art Museum, San Antonio, bequest of Marion Koogler McNay, 1950.46.

fig. 52.13 View of the American galleries at the Musée d’Ethnographie du Trocadéro, Paris, c. 1888, showing mummified human remains from Peru in the display case at the front left. Photograph: Musée de l’Homme, Paris.

fig. 52.14 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Peruvian Mummy, fol. 64V from the Album Walter, late 1880s. Graphite on paper; 15.4 × 9.4 cm (6 1/16 × 3 11/16 in.). Musée d'Orsay, Paris, RF 30569, 116.

fig. 52.15 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Peruvian Mummy, fol. 65R from the Album Walter, late 1880s. Graphite on paper; 15.4 × 9.4 cm (6 1/16 × 3 11/16 in.). Musée d'Orsay, Paris, RF 30569, 117.

fig. 52.16 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Parau na te varua ino (Words of the Devil), 1892. Oil on canvas; 91.7 × 68.5 cm (36 1/8 × 27 in.). National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C., gift of the W. Averell Harriman Foundation in memory of Marie N. Harriman, 1972.91.

fig. 52.17 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Preparatory Study for “Parau na te varua ino” (Words of the Devil), 1892. Graphite on paper; 22 × 21.5 cm (8 11/16 × 8 7/16 in.). Musée d’Orsay, Paris, RF 29.332.

fig. 52.19 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Parau hanohano (Terrifying Words), 1892. Oil on canvas; dimensions unknown. Private collection.

fig. 52.20 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Parau hanohano (Terrifying Words), c. 1892. Tamanu (?) wood; height, 21 cm (8 1/4 in.). Location unknown.

fig. 52.21 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Cover or Title Page Design for a Catalogue, 1893. Graphite on wove paper; 21.8 × 19.7 cm (8 9/16 × 7 3/4 in.). Location unknown.

fig. 52.22 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Preliminary Design for “Parau parau no” (Whispered Words), 1893. Pen and ink, selectively heightened with brush and ink on paper; 27 × 19 cm (10 5/8 × 7 1/2 in.). Location unknown.

fig. 52.23 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). O Tahiti, 1893. Brush and black ink on buff wove paper; 18.7 × 16.2 cm (7 3/8 × 6 3/8 in.). Private collection, Tahiti.

fig. 52.24 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Parau hanohano (A Frightening Tale), 1893/94. Zincograph on paper; 36 × 26.4 cm (14 3/16 ×10 3/8 in.). Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, gift of Henri M. Petiet, 2001.703.

fig. 52.26 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Fragment of Parau hanohano (A Frightening Tale), 1893/94, pasted onto the inside front cover of Avant et après (Before and After), 1903. Zincograph on paper. Location unknown. From Paul Gauguin, Avant et après, facsimile ed. (K. Wolff, 1918).

fig. 52.27 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Tahitian Figures in Repose and One Head in Profile, fol. 69R from the Carnet de Tahiti (Tahitian Sketchbook), c. 1893. fig. 52.30 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Moe moea (The Dream), 1892. Oil on canvas; 33 × 65 cm (13 × 25 9/16 in.). Private collection.

fig. 52.31 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Fragment of Te po (The Night), from the Noa Noa Suite, 1893/94, and fragment of Manao tupapau (She Thinks of the Ghost or The Ghost Thinks of Her) 1894/95 (see cat. 73.1 and cat. 73.2), pasted onto fol. 33R of the bound manuscript Noa Noa, Voyage de Tahiti, 1893–1901. Musée d’Orsay, Paris, given by Georges-Daniel de Monfreid, 1927, RF 7259.12.

The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of the Print and Drawing Club, 1950.1517.
